metadata.title: Bell OH-58 Kiowa
aws::graph::propositions: # Retirement of the Bell OH-58 Kiowa
The U.S. Army's first attempt to replace the Bell OH-58 Kiowa was the RAH-66 Comanche.
The RAH-66 Comanche was part of the Light Helicopter Experimental program.
The RAH-66 Comanche program was canceled in 2004.
Airframe age and losses led to the Armed Reconnaissance Helicopter program.
The Bell ARH-70 was developed under the Armed Reconnaissance Helicopter program.
The Bell ARH-70 program was canceled in 2008.
The Bell ARH-70 program was canceled due to cost overruns.
The Armed Aerial Scout program was the third replacement effort for the Bell OH-58 Kiowa.
The OH-58F Kiowa's planned retirement was extended from 2025 to 2036.
The OH-58F Kiowa's retirement extension was due to uncertainty in the Armed Aerial Scout program.
The OH-58F Kiowa's retirement extension was also due to fiscal restraints.
The Bell OH-58 Kiowa's scout role was supplemented by tactical unmanned aerial vehicles.
The Bell OH-58 Kiowa and tactical unmanned aerial vehicles often acted in conjunction.
The Bell OH-58 Kiowa and tactical unmanned aerial vehicles provided reconnaissance together.
The combined use of Bell OH-58 Kiowa and unmanned aerial vehicles exposed crews to less risk.
The OH-58F Kiowa had the ability to control unmanned aerial vehicles directly.
The OH-58F Kiowa could safely perform scout missions by controlling unmanned aerial vehicles.

text:
### Retirement
The U.S. Army's first attempt to replace the OH-58 was the RAH-66 Comanche of the Light Helicopter Experimental program, which was canceled in 2004. Airframe age and losses led to the Armed Reconnaissance Helicopter program and the Bell ARH-70, which was canceled in 2008 due to cost overruns. The third replacement effort was the Armed Aerial Scout program. Due to uncertainty in the AAS program and fiscal restraints, the OH-58F's planned retirement was extended from 2025 to 2036. The Kiowa's scout role was supplemented by tactical unmanned aerial vehicles, the two platforms often acting in conjunction to provide reconnaissance to expose crews to less risk. The OH-58F had the ability to control UAVs directly to safely perform scout missions.
